titleStmt.title: Every accession of originality
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

Redistribution or republication on other terms, in any medium, requires express written consent from the editors and advance notification of the publisher, Center for Digital Research in the Humanities. Permission to reproduce the graphic images in this archive has been granted by the owners of the originals for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: The quotation on this manuscript comes from John Forster's Statesmen of the Commonwealth of England, published by Harper & Brothers in five volumes in 1846. Whitman reviewed two of the volumes in the Brooklyn Daily Eagle on July 27 and September 4, 1846. Neither of the reviews contain the quotation from this manuscript, but it is likely that it dates from a similar time. An image of the verso is currently unavailable.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Every accession of originality
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original item.

revisionDesc.change: checked; revised repository information in header

body.p: "Every accession of originality of thought," says the author of Statesmen of the Commonwealth of England, "brings with it necessarily an accession of a certain originality of style."
